column13: Fix OpenSSL linking on MacOS
column20:
Resolves #63.
See commit messages.
@jeffaco I kind of had to guess at the right way to slip this information into OMI's build system (there docs anywhere on how to do this right?). As it is, it works. But I'm afraid ./install will fail because buildtool isn't updated. However, I didn't update buildtool because it seems like duplicated logic. configure does not use buildtool to setup OpenSSL flags, except when it generates install; it makes no sense!
Note that if the user of configure did not pass any OpenSSL flags at all, and Homebrew's OpenSSL was not found, configure exits with 1 as the default "OpenSSL" library (it's not OpenSSL) on OS X does not work with OMI.
column21:

column21:
I'd like to discuss this with you. Wouldn't it be nicer to just use the OpenSSL version that Apple ships? They use OpenSSL, so it should be possible to just use theirs rather than install an independent second version.
Let's discuss please, thanks.

column13: Fix OpenSSL linking on MacOS
column20:
Resolves #63.
See commit messages.
@jeffaco I kind of had to guess at the right way to slip this information into OMI's build system (there docs anywhere on how to do this right?). As it is, it works. But I'm afraid ./install will fail because buildtool isn't updated. However, I didn't update buildtool because it seems like duplicated logic. configure does not use buildtool to setup OpenSSL flags, except when it generates install; it makes no sense!
Note that if the user of configure did not pass any OpenSSL flags at all, and Homebrew's OpenSSL was not found, configure exits with 1 as the default "OpenSSL" library (it's not OpenSSL) on OS X does not work with OMI.
column21:
@jeffaco Apple does not ship OpenSSL. Apple deprecated OpenSSL in favor of their own library. I completely agree that a better, long-term solution is to rewrite OMI to use Apple's SSL libraries; but that's far more work than we (read: I) can do right now (also, I tried calling you earlier exactly about this ðŸ˜„ ).
Edit: OMI was previously fixed to use actual OpenSSL (installed through Homebrew), and .NET Core requires OpenSSL. So for the purposes of PowerShell remoting, this is not an additional dependency.

column13: SSL init only once, stabilize failed connections
column20:
ssl initialization only needs to be called once per process. doing it
more than once can mess itself up or other threads that are using ssl.
fixed couple of issues when connecting to a bad destination... still not
so great, but getting better.

column13: Client-side timeout changes
column20:
Propagate timeout error if one happens from the client -- needs to be
properly handled as it is sending an invalid MI_Result, but it is
better than sending a success
Make client socket timeout be a little more than the operation timeout
sent to the server so server has time to send an actual response
This partially addresses #112 - client not reporting timeout error, although needs to send a proper error code going forwards, as well as full fix for #113 - client needs to wait a little longer than the server is given to respond.

@microsoft/omi-devs @Microsoft/ostc-devs @yakman2020  @palladia

column13: Add support for FIPS mode in SSL 1.0.x
column20:
If FIPS mode is enabled/required, then we must have linkages to
"hidden" .hmac libraries. Something like this would fit the bill
(on RedHat/CentOS systems):
ln -s /usr/lib64/.libssl.so.10.hmac .libssl.so.1.0.0.hmac
ln -s /usr/lib64/.libcrypto.so.10.hmac .libcrypto.so.1.0.0.hmac

Do this in a general way to support FIPS mode on many of our platforms
(RedHat, CentOS, Oracle, SuSE).
@Microsoft/omi-devs @Microsoft/ostc-devs
column21:
If FIPS mode is enabled/required, then we must have linkages to
"hidden" .hmac libraries. Something like this would fit the bill
(on RedHat/CentOS systems):

ln -s /usr/lib64/.libcrypto.so.10.hmac .libcrypto.so.1.0.0.hmac

Do this in a general way to support FIPS mode on many of our platforms
(RedHat, CentOS, Oracle, SuSE).
@Microsoft/omi-devs @Microsoft/ostc-devs

column13: Migrate httpsport and sslciphersuite values from old omiserver.conf
column21:
Upgrading on debian systems will prompt the user with:
Configuration file '/etc/opt/omi/conf/omiserver.conf'
==> Modified (by you or by a script) since installation.
==> Package distributor has shipped an updated version.
What would you like to do about it ?  Your options are:
Y or I  : install the package maintainer's version
N or O  : keep your currently-installed version
D     : show the differences between the versions
Z     : start a shell to examine the situation
The default action is to keep your current version.
*** omiserver.conf (Y/I/N/O/D/Z) [default=N] ?
The default (keep current version) works just fine.  In the future, we might want to manage our own conf files instead of having them managed by the native packagers.  I think it adds more complexity than it is worth

column13: Add xmldeserializer and update tests
column20:
xmlserializer was not tested properly when another version was pulled
into this tree as the product code was updated but not the test code.
The updated external test code relied on both serializer and
deserializer, so the easiest way to pull in the proper test code was to
also pull in the deserializer. Now we have a full set of tests for
serializer (and deserializer!).
@microsoft/omi-devs
Note that all new code was pulled from an external source tree. Only minor changes were needed in the existing code.

column20:
Disable wchar option on configure and regress so we no longer validate
this build flavor. This is an unused flavor of OMI so there is no point
in maintaining compatibility. It has been left in the files as commented
out in case we do need to re-enable it.
Fixes issue #273

column13: Fix SLIST on PPC due to memory cache problems
column20:
Memory ordering on PPC is different to X86/AMD and so just because one
chunk of memory is synchronized does not mean others are. This change
adds a memory block around the locking and unlocking of the SLIST so all
relevant memory in the SLIST is properly pulled into the processor
memory cache.
@microsoft/omi-devs
column21:
Memory ordering on PPC is different to X86/AMD and so just because one
chunk of memory is synchronized does not mean others are. This change
adds a memory block around the locking and unlocking of the SLIST so all
relevant memory in the SLIST is properly pulled into the processor
memory cache.
@microsoft/omi-devs

column13: Fix AIX libgssapi library loading
column20: We are currently failing to load the libgssapi_krb5 library because AIX uses shared objects in an archive file for some reason. This requires different flags and file name to load.  With this fix, AIX loads the file correctly.

column13: Issue #292: omicli noop -synchronous doesn't generate output
Issue #292: omicli noop -synchronous doesn't generate output
column21:
you got the issue number wrong in the commit. I recommend putting that in the description of the pull request instead of in commit message!  That is the recommended way of doing this. If we happen to move (not likely to happen, but!) to a different source control all the issue numbers would relate to something wrong.
make sure the commit title is less that 70 characters.
please include @microsoft/omi-devs alias in the description when creating the pull request when ready for us to review.

column13: Update Readme to add unixes
Ported some changes from httpclientcxx 1.0.6.5 for socket cleanup.
column20: Porting some changes from the old httpclientcxx (omi version 1.0.6.5) that are used to close sockets. The "Cancel" function posts a NotifyItem to perform a "DELETE_HTTP" action, and used to exist in the old httpclientcxx file. I verified that this change (along with some assocaited changes in CM to call this function) resolves the socket leak issue.

I retriggered the Mac OS build, and everything succeeded.  These changes have no effect on an OMI build, since OMI does not build the deprecated folder by default.  SCXCM will build this file and include the resultant library with its package, so this change shouldn't require a new OMI release.  I believe I do not have the proper permissions to merge this to master, so I need someone with the right permissions to do so.

column21:
@lilyfang , in fact, OMS and docker-cimprov is not running in containers, it is running on host.
And from host it get all containers perf on the host: https://github.com/Microsoft/Docker-Provider/blob/master/source/code/providers/Container_ContainerStatistics_Class_Provider.cpp#L219
For collect perf of host, it need to configure on host:https://github.com/Microsoft/OMS-Agent-for-Linux/blob/master/docs/OMS-Agent-for-Linux.md#configuring-collected-data-on-the-linux-computer
All things are installed on host and not in containers, thanks.
OMS contains below parts:



Package
Version
Description




omsagent
1.1.0
The Operations Management Suite Agent for Linux


omsconfig
1.1.1
Configuration agent for the OMS Agent


omi
1.0.8.3
Open Management Infrastructure (OMI) -- a lightweight CIM Server


scx
1.6.2
OMI CIM Providers for operating system performance metrics


apache-cimprov
1.0.0
Apache HTTP Server performance monitoring provider for OMI. Only installed if Apache HTTP Server is detected.


mysql-cimprov
1.0.0
MySQL Server performance monitoring provider for OMI. Only installed if MySQL/MariaDB server is detected.


docker-cimprov
0.1.0
Docker provider for OMI. Only installed if Docker is detected.

column13: Fixed spnego tests. uses the hostname rather than localhost
column20: @omi-devs Because kerberos can and does have targets in the form scxuser@SCX.COM@myhost the nego code as well as kerberos use the hostname in the connection credentials. A result of that we need to quit using localhost as a connection name for spngo or kerberos connections.  This has been causing the nego tests to fail.
column21: @omi-devs Because kerberos can and does have targets in the form scxuser@SCX.COM@myhost the nego code as well as kerberos use the hostname in the connection credentials. A result of that we need to quit using localhost as a connection name for spngo or kerberos connections.  This has been causing the nego tests to fail.

column21:
To disable PBUILD on the Mac, running pbuild.py with --help is your friend. You'll note:
  --exclude=EXCLUDE     Overrides default exclude list from configuration file
                        (if any); comma-separated list of hosts to exclude
                        from the build

That's a very simple way to disable a single host (or a list of hosts) from a build. Sorry I missed this question earlier.

column13: Add  setup document for kerberos
column20:
There is doc for setting up kerberos and active directory, but it is very unfocused and most of it is some variety of wrong.  We have made some discoveries regarding what works and what doesn't in this environment. which can be useful going forward, and should be available.
The document is not complete, but has enough useful information that someone can setup a red hat 6 or 7 machine.  We don't have the same concise info regarding ubuntu, as they don't use authconfig so the setup is somewhat more manual. I am working on that right now. Until then, red hat is enough to get a good start

column13: Add support for query option in omiconfigeditor
column20:
@Microsoft/ostc-devs
omiconfigeditor will now support querying for a
given value in a property. If the value is found
then the exit code is 0 and if not then exit code
is 1.
Sample command:
omiconfigeditor httpsport -q 1270 < /etc/opt/omi/conf/omiserver.conf

column13: single selector and run thread per MI_Application
column20:
instead of having each request have its own run thread and selector now
a single selector is created per MI_Application along with an associated
Run thread. This selector is then passed in to the protocols and they
use that instead of their own.
@microsoft/omi-devs

column13: Fails http encrypt for basic auth
column20:
We had been silently accepting --encryption http and transmitting in the clear.   Since Basic auth can't do encryption, as it lacks a key, we should fail and now do.
In addition, this PR fixes some incompatibilities with the mac 10.12 clang compiler.
column21:
We had been silently accepting --encryption http and transmitting in the clear.   Since Basic auth can't do encryption, as it lacks a key, we should fail and now do.
In addition, this PR fixes some incompatibilities with the mac 10.12 clang compiler.

column13: Adding some features to support the OMI-Script-Provider.
column20:
The changes to provreg and provmgr add support for two new .reg file members,
interpreter and startup, which are used for identifying and starting providers
that use the OMI-Script-Provider.
The changes to omireg enable the omireg tool to read additional commandline
arguments from a configuration file to support registering providers for the
OMI-Script-Provider.  The use of the configuration file allows for future
scripting languages to be supprted without changing the OMI code.
column21:
The changes to provreg and provmgr add support for two new .reg file members,
interpreter and startup, which are used for identifying and starting providers
that use the OMI-Script-Provider.
The changes to omireg enable the omireg tool to read additional commandline
arguments from a configuration file to support registering providers for the
OMI-Script-Provider.  The use of the configuration file allows for future

column13: Adding some features to support the OMI-Script-Provider.
column20:
The changes to provreg and provmgr add support for two new .reg file members,
interpreter and startup, which are used for identifying and starting providers
that use the OMI-Script-Provider.
The changes to omireg enable the omireg tool to read additional commandline
arguments from a configuration file to support registering providers for the
OMI-Script-Provider.  The use of the configuration file allows for future
scripting languages to be supprted without changing the OMI code.

column13: Fix seg fault on some platforms
column20:
It was observed on pbuild of osdev64-cent5-01 and osd64-sls10-01 that seg fault happens during omiserver shutdown.
Investigations show that during shutdown, when Selector_RemoveAllHandlers() is called, a sequence of ProtocolSocket* functions are invoked:
_ProtocolSocket_Cleanup()
_ProtocolSocket_Close()
_ProtocolSocket_Finish()
_ProtocolSocket_Release()
Since both _ProtocolSocket_Finish() and _ProtocolSocket_Release() frees the allocated memory, one shouldn't call both.  The fix for now is to remove the _ProtocolSocket_Release() line.

column21:
1.IF we were going to set an environment variable, we would do it somewhere it would happen once. This is happening quite often and would be very inefficient.
2.But setting an environment variable inside the code at all isn't a good idea. There is a security cost to turning off the replay cache: krb5 would be unable to detect and defend from replay attacks. So this needs to be decided by the administrator.

The right place to debug this looks like in krb5 itself where it is losing the handles. I'm looking to see if the krb5 people have already done this, and if not we need to work with the platform owners to get it fixed.

column13: Add support for OMI to work with OpenSSL v1.1.*
column20:
@ostc-devs @Microsoft/omi-devs
A variety of changes were needed here:

Modify build system to build against OpenSSL v1.1.0,
Modify OMI (specifically base/credcache.c) to build with both old and new versions of OpenSSL,
Modify linkages (at run time) to recognize and link against OpenSSL v1.1.*.

For testing, I built on a universal build system to generate the omi-1.3.0-33.ssl_110.ulinux.x64.deb package. Debian 9 is currently the only system shipping with OpenSSL v1.1 by default, so I installed Debian 9 in a local VM, installed the omi package there, and verified that the identity provider ran properly.

column13: Fix memory leak for gss_acquire_cred()

@microsoft/omi-devs  I have fixed the memory fix for gss_acquire_cred() and I have verified the fix works, the memory of omiengine process keep on 1.0% from top command while running 10000 queries per second, could you help to review this PR? thanks very much!
This is the memory fix for previous release '1.3.0-2' omi version.
10000 queries per second command:
for i in {1..10000}; do /opt/omi/bin/omicli ei -u scxuser -p scxuserpasswd --auth NegoWithCreds --hostname omi64-cent7-05 --port 5985 --encryption none root/cimv2 TestClass_AllDMTFArrays;sleep 1; done

column13: Added features to support the OMI-Script-Provider.
column20:
These changes are needed to support the OMI-Script-Provider.
getopt.c:
added option arguments for command line args
configure:
added registration for omireg.conf
Base_OMI.data:
added file placement for omireg.conf
omireg.cpp:
added a configuration file to allow future additions for new scripting languages without core changes
added opening processing for script providers
added new arguments to the output files to support scripting providers
provmgr.c:
added an alternative processing case to handle scripting providers
provereg.[ch]:
added the members "interpreter" and "startup" to ProvRegEntry
regfile.[ch]:
added the members "interpreter" and "startup" to RegFile
messages.[ch]:
replaced "libraryName" and "instanceLifetimeContext" with "regEntry" in the RequestMsg structure.
agent.c:
support for the changes to the content of the RequestMsg data structure
agentmgr.c:
support for the changes to the content of the RequestMsg data structure

column13: Change how ULINUX is determined for InstallBuilder (fix AIXPPC platform).
column20:
ULINUX is sufficiently different that Linux where it makes sense to
have a separate InstallBuilder datafile just for ULINUX. This makes
it easier to inject ULINUX-specific code into pre/post installation
scripts.
@Microsoft/ostc-devs @Microsoft/omi-devs
Note that my last change broke the nightly build (OMI doesn't, by default, build packages in PBUILD). This is somewhat involved to fix in PBUILD (requires changes to .pbuild file for build hosts), will discuss that with the team.

column13: Resolve problems with psrp

column21:
Client logging was broken because the getting of the path was messed up. That fixed that.
The +2 error was because did not account for the extra cr-lf that terminates the http header
The writeclientheaders should be able to be called multiple times, we failed incorrectly before, and now we return _continue if we are not still writing headers.

column21:
@jeffaco , can I add a check with getdomainname() to determine if it is in the domain? or do you have other better option for checking it is joined the domain?
Note: POSIX does not specify these calls for getdomainname().
We should add the condition here: https://github.com/Microsoft/omi/blob/648f5c952849bf543050a966fcf23d2c5e5ec86b/Unix/server/server.c#L584
The error show only when omi start.

column13: Clean up omiserver.conf
column20:
@microsoft/omi-devs , could you help to review this PR? thanks very much!
here are changes:

Remove trace setting for both Unix/installbuilder/conf/omiserver.conf and Unix/etc/omiserver.conf (trace setting doesn't work, so remove it.)
Update loglevel section for Unix/etc/omiserver.conf
Add loglevel section for Unix/installbuilder/conf/omiserver.conf
Remove nonroot setting for both Unix/installbuilder/conf/omiserver.conf and Unix/etc/omiserver.conf
Update NICKNAME section description

For NICKNAME section, I have tried all below setting, they works fine:
prefix=GNU
libdir=/opt/omi/lib
bindir=/opt/omi/bin
localstatedir=/var/opt/omi
sysconfdir=/etc/opt/omi/conf
providerdir=/etc/opt/omi/conf
certsdir=/etc/opt/omi/ssl
datadir=/opt/omi/share
rundir=/var/opt/omi/run
logdir=/var/opt/omi/log
schemadir=/opt/omi/share/omischema
schemafile=/opt/omi/share/omischema/CIM_Schema.mof
pidfile=/var/opt/omi/run/omiserver.pid
logfile=/var/opt/omi/log/omiserver.log
registerdir=/etc/opt/omi/conf/omiregister
pemfile=/etc/opt/omi/ssl/omi.pem
keyfile=/etc/opt/omi/ssl/omikey.pem
agentprogram=/opt/omi/bin/omiagent
serverprogram=/opt/omi/bin/omiserver
includedir=/opt/omi/include
configfile=/etc/opt/omi/conf/omiserver.conf

column21:
@jeffaco , I removed the PATHs in installer conf, so you didn't see my comments in new review, I have made them back now. (I guess you were seeing from review page: https://github.com/Microsoft/omi/pull/469/files, in fact, you can see the many "Show outdated" items in PR page: #469, all old review comments are there.)
I have commentted all PATH in installer conf, they are default values and works fine after commentted out.
The only PATH can be modify to new location is "logfile", I have updated it in section comment.
For "NoTLS" related setting, I have removed them, thanks.
Previous 3 questions:

If these are here, we need to verify they work, not just with default location, but if moved to a new location, does everything still work properly?
Jumping: None of the directory or file path moved to new location will work except "logfile", I have tried one by one to move to /tmp. OMI related binaries now are very depended, it doesn't work now!

I have got following errors when move things to /tmp:
/tmp/opt
/tmp/var/opt
/tmp/etc/opt/omi
error 1:
/tmp/opt/omi/bin/omiengine: Protocol_New_Listener() failed: /var/opt/omi/run/omiserver.sock2017/12/06 20:43:05 [28658,28658] ERROR: null(0): Protocol_New_Listener() failed:

error 2:
/tmp/opt/omi/bin/omiserver: Launch failed: 22017/12/06 20:43:43 [28667,28667] ERROR: null(0): Launch failed: 409012848

error 3:
2017/12/06 20:57:28 [30984,30984] FATAL: null(0): EventId=10003 Priority=FATAL failed to initialize the dispatcher: 1
/opt/omi/bin/omiserver: failed to initialize the dispatcher: 12017/12/06 20:57:28 [30984,30984] ERROR: null(0): failed to initialize the dispatcher: 768683504

2.We need to decide if we want to support moving all of these things?
Jumping: We don't support moving omi things anymore now except "logfile".
3.For things that we depend on (like the un-commented out lines, if we indeed still depend on them), they should probably be moved to a different section with a note to not change or system may not work properly.
Jumping: Yes, they should not be changed and should notice that in a section, I have updated them, thanks.
I tried to moving with files under the 5 group directory and also individual file, but none of them work.
Group1:
prefix=GNU
libdir=/tmp/opt/omi/lib
includedir=/tmp/opt/omi/include

Group2:
bindir=/tmp/opt/omi/bin
agentprogram=/tmp/opt/omi/bin/omiagent
serverprogram=/tmp/opt/omi/bin/omiserver

Group3:
datadir=/tmp/opt/omi/share
schemadir=/tmp/opt/omi/share/omischema
schemafile=/tmp/opt/omi/share/omischema/CIM_Schema.mof

Group4:
localstatedir=/tmp/var/opt/omi

rundir=/tmp/var/opt/omi/run
pidfile=/tmp/var/opt/omi/run/omiserver.pid

logdir=/tmp/var/opt/omi/log
logfile=/tmp/var/opt/omi/log/omiserver.log

certsdir=/tmp/etc/opt/omi/ssl
pemfile=/tmp/etc/opt/omi/ssl/omi.pem
keyfile=/tmp/etc/opt/omi/ssl/omikey.pem

Group5:
sysconfdir=/tmp/etc/opt/omi/conf
providerdir=/tmp/etc/opt/omi/conf
registerdir=/tmp/etc/opt/omi/conf/omiregister
configfile=/tmp/etc/opt/omi/conf/omiserver.conf

Be sure that libssl.so/libcrypto.so are resolved.

Verify that the libraries are actually found or give a meaningful
error if not.

column13: Disable configuring of service manager for Docker env
column20:
On Docker systems, service manager may not work properly.  This commit introduces the environment variable OMI_DISABLE_SERVICE_START.  If set to non-null value, this will cause:

The installer to not configure service manager.
Disable /opt/omi/bin/service_control.

This means that on Docker systems where this is needed, one must manually start OMI after installation with command "sudo /opt/omi/bin/omiserver -d".  And run "sudo /opt/omi/bin/omiserver -s" to stop OMI before removing OMI package.

column21:
self-signed cert
The medium Pentest issue is about self-signed cert , and the self-signed cert should be ok for OMS or scx(they don't expose the cert to public, OMS call local binary protocol, and scx for OM are on-premised), and for PSRP, it might be exposing to public, when we say self-signed cert, we are considering it is a Linux/Unix server(Mac don't support server now), and when user are remoting from Windows to Linux, it really like the doc say it will not be notified about the remoting server is a self-signed cert on Windows side, if we really this fix I will new another PR for it, thanks.
3 options related PSRP
For 3 options related PSRP, that's NOT in the Pentest issues list, X509_V_ERR_HOSTNAME_MISMATCH is only supported by openssl 1.1.0 that is related to -skipcncheck, so it will fail for openssl less than 1.1.0, I don't have confident to make this PR go into product, and that doesn't related to the Pentest issue, after a long thinking, I want to close this PR, thanks.

@JumpingYang001 This does not fix the underlying problem of the operation instance being deleted before returning.  As I mentioned in when I reactivated the issue, In release builds, I'm seeing a process failure due to a double free.
Removing the ENABLE_CLEARING flag doesn't fix the root cause, that the call chain within Strand_ScheduleAux is deleting a pointer that it doesn't own.
In debug builds, this problem is caught in InteractionProtocolHandler_Session_Connect which attempts to use the freed memory.  In release builds, the problem is caught when the owner of the memory attempts to free it resulting in a double free.
This is exactly what was happening the first time around and this PR (ba1958e) fixed that case.
However, I'm hitting another error path, server not reachable, that is not fixed and there may be others.

column21: To repro the issue with exist release build: create 3~5 virtual network on Azure box, and run "initctl stop network-interface INTERFACE=eth1" and "initctl start network-interface INTERFACE=eth1", you will see it trigger omi to start/stop no matter omi is active or not, and do these things several times in same time, you will get omi go into strange/struggle issue.

column13: Avoid deadlock in Engine if Server dies
column20: If server dies unexpectedly, the lock in agentmgr could be locked twice.  Since our locks are not recursive, this second locking will cause engine to hang forever.

column21:
we have these 2 options in readme, and it works but need to aware some permission setting, so I add them. Once enable https, omi will load ssl cert and its private key as following:

2018/04/17 02:12:49 [30995,30995] INFO: null(0): EventId=40007 Priority=INFO ---> SSL: Loading server certificate from: /test/omi.pem
2018/04/17 02:12:49 [30995,30995] INFO: null(0): EventId=40008 Priority=INFO ---> SSL: Loading certificate's private key from: /test/omikey.pem 

We support this, and current cert are self-signed, if customer want to use their own Signed CA cert, then they will meet issue, this PR will help them go smoothly.


we load cert here: https://github.com/Microsoft/omi/blob/ba1958ec946fc7705550d4d78796d5719e54c2cd/Unix/http/http.c#L1660


I have tested on 2 platforms (CentOS7x64 and Ubuntu16.04x64), they works fine.


etc/omiserver.conf already have the setting: https://github.com/Microsoft/omi/blob/master/Unix/etc/omiserver.conf#L43, its value will be a relative path based on the path of current source code, you can run omiserver -p to check the values like below (only for debugging).

For other settings, I have tried them today, like move lib folder to other place, that will make omiserver and other binaries can't load the libs, so modify these settings doesn't make sense for production, for moving omiserver and other binaries to other place is also same with non-make sense(service_control also not work if you move binaries), moving /etc/opt/omi/conf folder get /opt/omi/bin/omiserver: error while loading shared libraries: libssl.so.1.0.0: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory, moving /var/opt/omi/run might works, but no one will move omiserver.pid or omiserver.sock, and that will be possible to cause issues.

column21:
When is this hitting azure production? A rhel VM I rolled out last week still has:
# crontab -l
* * * * * [ \( ! -f /etc/opt/omi/creds/omi.keytab \) -o \( /etc/krb5.keytab -nt /etc/opt/omi/creds/omi.keytab \) ] && /opt/omi/bin/support/ktstrip /etc/krb5.keytab /etc/opt/omi/creds/omi.keytab

Also I think your check is insufficient to update a preexisting configuration
https://github.com/Microsoft/omi/blob/master/Unix/scripts/config_keytab_update.sh#L15
is true for the "old" crontab line and so it won't replace it with a new one if config_keytab_update.sh is run. Not sure if that is actually the workflow you use though :)

For MS repo, we will update it once omi 1.6.0 release, thanks.

column21:
@palladia It should be okay, given that these are bit flags, and from what I can tell from the openssl source, they are only used with  "&" and "|" operators.
Here's some results of grep in Openssl 1.0.0, which doesn't have TLSv1_1/2, but it does have TLSv1_0:

If it doesn't work, then the solution will be significantly more complicated, where we'll need to dynamically detect the version of openssl running before we give it flags it may not know about that could break it. column21:
@johnkord @palladia
I have tested the code change in Ubuntu16 platform. It works fine.
like following steps:


run "openssl s_client -tls1_1 -connect localhost:1270"


add "NoTLSv1_1=true" to omiserver.conf


restart omiserver


run "openssl s_client -tls1_1 -connect localhost:1270"


run "openssl s_client -tls1_2 -connect localhost:1270"


add "NoTLSv1_2=true" to omiserver.conf


restart omiserver


run "openssl s_client -tls1_2 -connect localhost:1270"


I will ask CTI team to test this code change on other platforms tonight.

column13: Fixes double free issue
column20: @microsoft/omi-devs @dantraMSFT  , fixed the double free issue #502 , could you help to review it? thanks.
column21:
I don't see how this can fix #502 either.
The problem I saw was as follows:
InteractionProtocolHandler_Session_Connect calls WsmanClient_New_Connector with an allocated operation.  Before returning, the connection fails and the operation is freed.   This would be fine if WsmanClient_New_Connector returned a failing MI_RESULT  but it doesn't, it returns MI_RESULT_OK and the code assumes the operation is still a valid memory pointer.  As a result, the following line is executed:
if (operation->protocolConnection->protocol.wsman == NULL)
Since the operation has been freed, in debug builds, protocolConnection contains an invalid pointer value and we get a seg fault.  In release builds, we're accessing freed memory and it's state is indeterminate.
Even with the suggested changes, we'll get a seg fault because we'll be dereferencing a null pointer, protocolConnection.   If we add a protocolConnection null pointer check, we'll end up getting a random seg fault any time that memory block happens to get reused for something else.
The reliable fix needs to handle the case that operation itself has been freed.

column13: Support MS-WSMAN session cookies over HTTP
column20:
This change adds support for detecting and using the MS_WSMAN session cookie.  This is needed to maintain connections to sites behind a load balancer, such as office 365.
The change is in the following layers,

httpclient (httpclient.c, httpclient_private.h, httpclientauth.c),
wsmanclient (wsmanclient.c)
Interaction protocol (InteractionProtocolHandler.c)
Message.h (updates the base Message structure to support a session cookie)

The logic starts at the response from the target containing a Set-Cookie: MS-WSMAN:* header.  This is handled by the wsmanclient layer which detects and passes up using the base Message structure (typically via PostInstance)
InteractionProtocolHandler.c is responsible for detecting changes to the cookie value and saving it for the next request sent to the server. At that point, the session cookie is added to the MI_DestinationOptions passed down to create the connection.  Note that not all messages sent from wsmanclient to interaction protocol contains a session cookie.
Finally, the http layer is responsible for adding the Cookie header on the next request.

column13: Fix stale operation instance for connection error paths
column20:
Fix #502
This change adds a reference count to the InteractionProtcolHandler_Operation structure to address the race condition between InteractionProtocolHandler_Operation_Strand_Finish and InteractionProtocolHandler_Session_CommonInstanceCode.
For connection errors, the operation instance was being freed before returning to InteractionProtocolHandler_Session_Connect. This resulted in Session_Connect referencing a stale instance pointer and, later, a double free to occur on the operation instance.
The fix is as follows:
1: Set the reference count to 2 when the operation created

1 refcount ensures the lifetime is valid until control is returned to InteractionProtocolHandler_Session_CommonInstanceCode
1 refcount is for Strand_Finish to use when releasing the operation.

2: Remove the PAL_Free(operation) call from the error path in InteractionProtocolHandler_Operation_Close. This was causing a double free in error paths.
For error paths, the final release occurs in CommonInstanceCode since Finish has already been called.
For success paths, the final release typically occurs in Finish sometime after CommonInstanceCode has released it's reference.
column21:
Fix #502
This change adds a reference count to the InteractionProtcolHandler_Operation structure to address the race condition between InteractionProtocolHandler_Operation_Strand_Finish and InteractionProtocolHandler_Session_CommonInstanceCode.
For connection errors, the operation instance was being freed before returning to InteractionProtocolHandler_Session_Connect. This resulted in Session_Connect referencing a stale instance pointer and, later, a double free to occur on the operation instance.
The fix is as follows:
1: Set the reference count to 2 when the operation created

1 refcount ensures the lifetime is valid until control is returned to InteractionProtocolHandler_Session_CommonInstanceCode
1 refcount is for Strand_Finish to use when releasing the operation.

2: Remove the PAL_Free(operation) call from the error path in InteractionProtocolHandler_Operation_Close. This was causing a double free in error paths.
For error paths, the final release occurs in CommonInstanceCode since Finish has already been called.
For success paths, the final release typically occurs in Finish sometime after CommonInstanceCode has released it's reference.

column13: Handle session cookies to office365.com
column20:
Fix #523
This change places management of the session cookie in the HttpClient layer.  There are four basic parts:

TransactionProtocolHandler: Generates a session id for the current MI_Session and passes it to the HttpClient layer via MI_DestinationOptions.
SessionMap - a HashMap providing a mapping between a session id and an HTTP cookie.
HttpClient.c - adds/updates the SessionMap when a response is recieved with a MS-WSMAN cookie using the id created by TransactionProtocolHandler.  Ensures subsequent requests also include the session cookie.
NOTE: With office365, the session cookie changes virtually on every response and a single cookie cannot be used.
TransactionProtocolHandler removes the session id from the SessionMap when the session is destroyed. This is done via a call to a new  export HttpClient_RemoveSession.

NOTE: The current implementation initializes the HashMap on first use since there is no clear global initialization point.  Since there is also no clear global cleanup, the internal HashMap array is also leaked on shutdown.  Allocations for hashMap entries should not be leaked since MI_Session clean removes the associated entry.
Unlike the previous attempt, this approach is able to track the session cookie for all types of responses and solves the case where an error, such as an timeout, can cause the cookie to stale for the next request.

column13: Log a session id and datetime stamp at the start of logging HTTP headers
column20:
Fix: #544
The intent of this change is to provide a session id and date/time stamp in the debug logs for httpclient (omiclient-sent.trc and omiclient-recv.trc).  It aids in correlating http traces with a given session id and includes the timestamp for the sent/recieved http headers.
Previously, omiclient-sent.trc contained no date/time information and omiclient-recv.trc relied on the Date header in the response.  This made correlating between the two log files error prone, at best.


Example omiclient-recv.trc log:
[Session: 1 Date: 2018-07-18 00:31:36.0449595Z]
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Cache-Control: private
Content-Type: application/soap+xml;charset=UTF-8
...


Example omiclient-recv.trc log:
[Session: 1 Date: 2018-07-18 00:31:17.0553452Z]
POST /powershell-liveid?PSVersion=6.1.0 HTTP/1.1
Connection: Keep-Alive
Content-Length: 47119
Content-Type: application/soap+xml;charset=UTF-8
...

column13: Fixes preexec issue with multiple requests
column20: The class _ConnectionIn uses operationId as key to check for duplicate entries in hash table.  This causes multiple preexec requests to be ignored.

column21:
I have verified the cases, here is my steps:

Install omi
Enable loglevel=VERBOSE in /etc/opt/omi/conf/omiserver.conf and restart omi service.
Run while true; do /opt/omi/bin/omicli id;done
Waiting about 1 hour, check grep CRON /var/log/cron or grep CRON /var/log/syslog doesn't contains error and check files under /var/opt/omi/log/ are actually rotated.

Below is the result:

we have tested the feature on all Linux platforms today, currently, 6 platforms failed to logrotate due to selinux are enabled: ost64-rh6-01, ost64-rh7-01,  ost64-ct6-01, ost64-ct7-01, ost64-ora6-01, ost64-ora7-01. (other platforms' selinux are disabled by default in our Lab)
so my next plan should be supporting the selinux enable feature for logrotate. (I ask Jeane, they support both selinux enable and disable)

column13: Fixes thunk handle
column20: Fixed #448 , @palladia @paulcallen , can you help to review it? thanks.
column21:
cancelling an already shutdown handle is OK as long as the application is not shut down which implies more serious problems in the flow of an application not this code.
What you have done here is nothing more than an unreliable band aid that really does not solve the threading issue. If you don't like the error, make it a warning! This error is likely to happen in ordinary code so it is an interesting warning of misuse of the handle, but not really a problem. These are thunk handles to protect race conditions like the one you are seeing. It makes doing what is happening here safe. If it is crashing that is a different story, but I believe you just have a problem with the debug message and find it alarming.

column21:
BTW, our ktstrip will only keep service principle name contains 'host' or 'RestrictedKrbHost' after run the ktstrip here: https://github.com/Microsoft/omi/blob/1879df398a03201628a34cffe3fea47c3a828aa2/Unix/tools/ktstrip#L74 .
If there is not  'host' or 'RestrictedKrbHost' keep service principle name in /etc/krb5.keytab, then you will reproduce the #570 issue, that's part of this PR fixes.
Another part of this PR fixes is removing the tmp files using mktemp.

column13: Improve config_keytab_update.sh

column21: @palladia , can you help to approve it? I think the option is a nice help for customers who want to remove the cron they don't want to use. the maker file path I followed our docker container fixes. thanks very much for help!

column13: Improve config_keytab_update.sh

column13: Decrypt authorized message sent over HTTPS
column20:
Previously a check was performed to see if the current message was
sent over SSL. In cases where the message was sent as
Content-Type: multipart/encrypted, the message would be improperly parsed
resulting in a 401 unauthorized being sent to the client.
By all accounts, the PSRP implementation on Windows in PowerShell 5 and
PowerShell 6 allows a multipart/encrypted message to be sent in response
to the challenge message.
Since the Http_DecryptData function already ignores / returns immediately
for messages that are not multipart/encrypted, this change should
simply make the protocol handling more tolerant.


This fixes an issue when trying to establish a connection to an OMI server
from the WinRM Ruby library where NTLM/SPNEGO is enabled in the OMI server.

column21:
@dantraMSFT / @mwrock - I wanted to open this up and get a conversation started on the protocol handling here. I haven't fully read through all the relevant specs yet, but it's my understanding that the NTLMSSP_AUTH generated in response to a NTLMSSP_CHALLENGE can be multipart/encrypted over HTTPS as I've observed with the WinRM gem.
I have done a number of traces with WireShark to look at the sequence of messages from various clients (PowerShell 5 and 6 on Windows, PowerShell 6 on Linux, omicli on Linux, winrm gem) to various servers to get a better understanding of what's happening. The WinRM gem successfully connects to a Windows host using a multipart/encrypted response to the challenge (message construction code is at https://github.com/WinRb/WinRM/blob/master/lib/winrm/http/transport.rb#L111-L120). However, when trying to connect to OMI server, the OMI code completely skips the multipart/encrypted decoding as mentioned in this PR.
That said, two other clients respond to the server differently. The OMI client application on Linux sends an empty Body of application/soap+xml and the server returns 200. PowerShell 6.1 on Windows, when using the Enter-PSSession cmdlet, also sends application/soap+xml, with a non-empty Body that includes creation Xml to create a PowerShell instance (obviously these payloads are influenced by the action they're taking).
Given my understanding is SPNEGO can be sent over HTTPS during this part of the protocol lifecycle and given the standard PowerShell endpoint on Windows accepts a message of this Content-Type, I'm inclined to believe that OMI server should follow the same behavior. But, as I mentioned, I haven't really dug into the protocol spec enough to know for certain if OMI is following the protocol more strictly... and I haven't looked closely enough at this codebase to understand if the current processing is intentional for that or other reasons.
Once this change is made, at least OMI server decrypts the message, parses the SOAP message and tries to proceed. It actually ends up with another issue immediately after that based on the message that the gem sends. That message looks like this:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<env:Envelope xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" 
    xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" 
    xmlns:env="http://www.w3.org/2003/05/soap-envelope" 
    xmlns:a="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2004/08/addressing" 
    xmlns:b="http://schemas.dmtf.org/wbem/wsman/1/cimbinding.xsd" 
    xmlns:n="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2004/09/enumeration" 
    xmlns:x="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2004/09/transfer" 
    xmlns:w="http://schemas.dmtf.org/wbem/wsman/1/wsman.xsd" 
    xmlns:p="http://schemas.microsoft.com/wbem/wsman/1/wsman.xsd" 
    xmlns:rsp="http://schemas.microsoft.com/wbem/wsman/1/windows/shell" 
    xmlns:cfg="http://schemas.microsoft.com/wbem/wsman/1/config">
    <env:Header>
        <a:To>https://172.28.54.141:5986/wsman</a:To>
        <a:ReplyTo>
            <a:Address mustUnderstand="true">http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2004/08/addressing/role/anonymous</a:Address>
        </a:ReplyTo>
        <w:MaxEnvelopeSize mustUnderstand="true">153600</w:MaxEnvelopeSize>
        <a:MessageID>uuid:B62FFCAA-CBE3-4DC5-9103-B87D99D42AA2</a:MessageID>
        <p:SessionId mustUnderstand="false">uuid:93D0EB38-EBD3-4358-9E0E-F9794556C709</p:SessionId>
        <w:Locale xml:lang="en-US" mustUnderstand="false"/>
        <p:DataLocale xml:lang="en-US" mustUnderstand="false"/>
        <w:OperationTimeout>PT60S</w:OperationTimeout>
        <w:ResourceURI mustUnderstand="true">http://schemas.microsoft.com/wbem/wsman/1/config</w:ResourceURI>
        <a:Action mustUnderstand="true">http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2004/09/transfer/Get</a:Action>
    </env:Header>
    <env:Body></env:Body>
</env:Envelope>
OMI server code throws an error from https://github.com/Microsoft/omi/blob/edbe231042173018c52903e4170dd8b782fc4f8a/Unix/wsman/wsman.c#L2012 about get-instance: instance name parameter is missing, which I'm still working on. I haven't gotten far enough to know if OMI server should accept the message payload that the gem has sent or if it's really invalid. (FWIW, I did modify the WinRM gem code to send a different response. An emtpy message worked OK, but a KeepAlive message didn't). But again, this initial message is parsed OK by a PowerShell Windows endpoint and doesn't seem to cause any errors in that environment.
Any input here is welcome!

column13: Decrypt authorized message sent over HTTPS
column20:
Previously a check was performed to see if the current message was
sent over SSL. In cases where the message was sent as
Content-Type: multipart/encrypted, the message would be improperly parsed
resulting in a 401 unauthorized being sent to the client.
By all accounts, the PSRP implementation on Windows in PowerShell 5 and
PowerShell 6 allows a multipart/encrypted message to be sent in response
to the challenge message.
Since the Http_DecryptData function already ignores / returns immediately
for messages that are not multipart/encrypted, this change should
simply make the protocol handling more tolerant.


This fixes an issue when trying to establish a connection to an OMI server
from the WinRM Ruby library where NTLM/SPNEGO is enabled in the OMI server.
column21:
UPDATE: I think I understand why the message being sent is failing to parse. The WinRM gem is issuing a config request message, which I believe is part of a set of WSMV protocol extensions that neither OMI server or the PSRP OMI provider supports.
MS-WSMV 4.2.1 covers this message - which looks like:
<s:Envelope xmlns:s="http://www.w3.org/2003/05/soap-envelope" 
             xmlns:wsa="http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2004/08/addressing" 
             xmlns:wsman="http://schemas.dmtf.org/wbem/wsman/1/wsman.xsd">
     <s:Header>
         <wsa:To>http://localhost:80/wsman</wsa:To>
         <wsman:ResourceURI s:mustUnderstand="true">
           http://schemas.microsoft.com/wbem/wsman/1/config
         </wsman:ResourceURI>
         <wsa:ReplyTo>
             <wsa:Address s:mustUnderstand="true">
 http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2004/08/addressing/role/anonymous
             </wsa:Address>
         </wsa:ReplyTo>
         <wsa:Action s:mustUnderstand="true">
 http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2004/09/transfer/Get
         </wsa:Action>
         <wsman:MaxEnvelopeSize s:mustUnderstand="true">
           51200
         </wsman:MaxEnvelopeSize>
         <wsa:MessageID>
           uuid:613DCD71-95AF-4ED5-86E2-1D6AB44ECE66
         </wsa:MessageID>
         <wsman:OperationTimeout>PT60.000S</wsman:OperationTimeout>
     </s:Header>
     <s:Body/>
 </s:Envelope>
This looks pretty familiar as it would appear to be the same request the WinRM gem is sending (WinRM sends a few extra options in the SOAP header)
It looks like the OMI client understands to ask for this at https://github.com/Microsoft/omi/blob/4a0b6ebabdce442c3e526cd47fb326425aeed79a/Unix/wsman/wsmanclient.c#L1399-L1406, but given it's coded defensively, I'm assuming there's no expectation that all servers respond?

column21:
I'm still plugging along (slowly) on getting the gem talking to the OMI server. I was able to create a fallback in the WinRM gem for the max envelope size when the server doesn't accept config requests (like OMI)
I've found an issue with the shell creation xml payload that the winrm gem sends. The OMI server code is expecting the shell to have a Name attribute in the XML per the code at / like the following example: https://github.com/Microsoft/omi/blob/232a38192e16ca724f3f3438419f8ccaead10f34/Unix/wsman/wsmanparser.c#L2126
<rsp:Shell xmlns:rsp="http://schemas.microsoft.com/wbem/wsman/1/windows/shell" Name="Runspace3" ShellId="DC96D496-39F6-49D1-978C-CC6F32F99CC9">
However, the winrm gem does not set one at https://github.com/WinRb/WinRM/blob/master/lib/winrm/wsmv/init_runspace_pool.rb#L38 when creating the SOAP message body.  Once that's fixed OMI responds with a 200. Then it's on to the next problem!

to the challenge message.
Since the Http_DecryptData function already ignores / returns immediately
for messages that are not multipart/encrypted, this change should
simply make the protocol handling more tolerant.


This fixes an issue when trying to establish a connection to an OMI server
from the WinRM Ruby library where NTLM/SPNEGO is enabled in the OMI server.
column21: This change looks fine, just removing the prerequisite of decrypting only when not using SSL. We should run some internal tests on this to validate a few different scenarios though before committing it.

column13: Decrypt authorized message sent over HTTPS
column20:
Previously a check was performed to see if the current message was
sent over SSL. In cases where the message was sent as
Content-Type: multipart/encrypted, the message would be improperly parsed
resulting in a 401 unauthorized being sent to the client.
By all accounts, the PSRP implementation on Windows in PowerShell 5 and
PowerShell 6 allows a multipart/encrypted message to be sent in response
to the challenge message.
Since the Http_DecryptData function already ignores / returns immediately
for messages that are not multipart/encrypted, this change should
simply make the protocol handling more tolerant.


This fixes an issue when trying to establish a connection to an OMI server
from the WinRM Ruby library where NTLM/SPNEGO is enabled in the OMI server.

column13: Allow writing SPNEGO responses over HTTPS
column20:
Previously a check was performed when writing headers to see if the current
handler is operating over SSL. In cases where the message was sent as
Content-Type: multipart/encrypted, the message response would be returned
as application/soap+xml if the transport was HTTPS. This could confuse
clients (such as the winrm gem) as they are expecting a response of
multipart/encrypted.
By all accounts, the PSRP implementation on Windows in PowerShell 5 and
PowerShell 6 allows multipart/encrypted spnego messages to be sent over
HTTPS.
Since the code already checks for handler->encryptedTransaction prior to
determining how to write response headers, it is safe to remove the SSL
check to allow mulitpart/encrypted over HTTPS. This change should
simply make the protocol handling more tolerant.


This fixes an issue when trying to establish a connection to an OMI server
from the WinRM Ruby library where NTLM/SPNEGO is enabled in the OMI server.


Similarly change the behavior in httpclient.c to match what has been changed
on the server response writing in this commit, and the server request
reading in the prior commit ebe43ea

column21:
Like PR #577, this removes ->ssl guards when sending responses to clients. Clients that are sending Content-Type: multipart/encrypted messages expect to receive responses in the same manner.
I was able to get a fully fleshed out PR (with tests that include real messages from OMI server) up against the winrm gem to fix the interop issues I encountered at WinRb/WinRM#288
I've traced the message flow in WireShark and with this patch, I see the expected responses being generated by the server - and the client is able to decrypt / process the messages correctly. I've additionally tested using Enter-PSSession from a Windows host with PowerShell 6.1.0 and found everything to behave correctly.  This is probably something that should have some tests, but I figured I would leave that up to the MS team.
Thanks for having a look @paulcallen @yakman2020 @JumpingYang001

column13: Improve upstart and systemd
Improve upstart and systemd
column21:
We have verified below tests on all x64 Linux systems:

Install omi
Run omicli id
service_control restart/start/stop/reload
reboot machine, check if omi is still active.
Uninstall omi

Also tried the systemd crash case and my PR fixed the issue:

kill systemd, ln -s /bin/ls /sbin/initctl, install omi, and omi works fine on Ubuntu16.0 with this PR.
kill systemd, ln -s /bin/ls /sbin/initctl, install omi, and omi will meet upstart issue with omi 1.5.0 on Ubuntu16.0

column13: Improves omid.service when systemd not ready
column20:
@microsoft/omi-devs, found a systemd configuration issue when systemd process crash.
When systemd crash:
1.Expect omi installation logic: Systemd logic should copy the omid.systemd to omid.service and reload it and enable it.
2.Current omi installation logic: In fact, my previous fix and case go to use line 191-192:
https://github.com/Microsoft/omi/blob/master/Unix/installbuilder/datafiles/Linux.data#L191-L192
My previous works fine for the scenario, because systemd load /etc/init.d/omid, but it should load /lib/systemd/system/omid.service even the wrong logic works.

column21:
we remove SEPOLICY_DIR_EL6 and add SEPOLICY_DIR_EL5, the reason is that:


omi-logrotate.el6.te never used.


redhat 5 don't have open permission setting. allow init_t var_t:file open;
other higher OS have open permission setting, so we add red hat 5 selinux different setting.

column13: Fixes /opt be removed when dpkg -P omi
column20:
@microsoft/omi-devs
This PR fixes dpkg -P omi will remove /opt folder on debian/ubuntu systems, the root cause is dpkg -P by design will remove package installed folder if its sub-folders and sub-files are removed, more detail:
Same issue: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/13021002/my-deb-file-removes-opt
Related on debian discussion:
https://lists.debian.org/debian-devel/2006/03/msg00224.html
https://lists.debian.org/debian-devel/2006/03/msg00214.html
BTW, dpkg -P omi or dpkg --purge omi will not pass "$1" as "purge" as below, so I check PERFORMING_PURGE_REMOVE_FOR_DPKG: '[ "$1" = "purge" -o "$1" = "remove" ]' value in code.
~
root@ost64-deb8-02  # dpkg --purge omi
(Reading database ... 30127 files and directories currently installed.)
Removing omi (1.6.0.230) ...

**test:remove**  # here I print "test:$1"

Unconfiguring omid service ...
2019-06-12 01:01:44 : Crontab no longer configured to update omi keytab.
Deleting omiusers group ...
Deleting omi service account ...
Purging configuration files for omi (1.6.0.230) ...
dpkg: warning: while removing omi, directory '/var/opt/omi/log' not empty so not removed
dpkg: warning: while removing omi, directory '/etc/opt/omi/ssl' not empty so not removed
dpkg: warning: while removing omi, directory '/etc/opt/omi/conf/sockets' not empty so not removed

After the fixes, output of dpkg -P omi shows as below:
~
root@ost64-deb8-02  # dpkg -P omi
(Reading database ... 30127 files and directories currently installed.)
Removing omi (1.6.0.230) ...
Unconfiguring omid service ...
2019-06-12 01:07:41 : Crontab no longer configured to update omi keytab.
Deleting omiusers group ...
Deleting omi service account ...
Purging configuration files for omi (1.6.0.230) ...
dpkg: warning: while removing omi, directory '/opt/omi' not empty so not removed
dpkg: warning: while removing omi, directory '/var/opt/omi/log' not empty so not removed
dpkg: warning: while removing omi, directory '/etc/opt/omi/ssl' not empty so not removed
dpkg: warning: while removing omi, directory '/etc/opt/omi/conf/sockets' not empty so not removed

column20:
@microsoft/omi-devs
This PR fixes dpkg -P omi will remove /opt folder on debian/ubuntu systems, the root cause is dpkg -P by design will remove package installed folder if its sub-folders and sub-files are removed, more detail:
Same issue: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/13021002/my-deb-file-removes-opt
Related on debian discussion:
https://lists.debian.org/debian-devel/2006/03/msg00224.html
https://lists.debian.org/debian-devel/2006/03/msg00214.html
BTW, dpkg -P omi or dpkg --purge omi will not pass "$1" as "purge" as below, so I check PERFORMING_PURGE_REMOVE_FOR_DPKG: '[ "$1" = "purge" -o "$1" = "remove" ]' value in code.

(Reading database ... 30127 files and directories currently installed.)

dpkg: warning: while removing omi, directory '/etc/opt/omi/conf/sockets' not empty so not removed
column21:
more detail about why $1 is "remove" for this fixes:
A. 3 uninstall scripts only the last 2 scripts call "purge", and the 1st uninstall script doesn't call "purge":
~
root@ost64-deb8-02  # dpkg -P omi
(Reading database ... 30127 files and directories currently installed.)
Removing omi (1.6.0.230) ...
Preuninstall_10:remove
Unconfiguring omid service ...
2019-06-13 21:33:06 : Crontab no longer configured to update omi keytab.
Postuninstall_100:remove
Deleting omiusers group ...
Deleting omi service account ...
Postuninstall_1500:remove
Purging configuration files for omi (1.6.0.230) ...
Postuninstall_100:purge
Postuninstall_1500:purge
dpkg: warning: while removing omi, directory '/opt/omi' not empty so not removed
dpkg: warning: while removing omi, directory '/var/opt/omi/log' not empty so not removed
dpkg: warning: while removing omi, directory '/etc/opt/omi/ssl' not empty so not removed
dpkg: warning: while removing omi, directory '/etc/opt/omi/conf/sockets' not empty so not removed

B. If we put touch file in Postuninstall_100 or Postuninstall_1500, /opt already removed when Postuninstall_100 and Postuninstall_1500:
~
root@ost64-deb8-02  # dpkg -P omi
(Reading database ... 30127 files and directories currently installed.)
Removing omi (1.6.0.230) ...
Preuninstall_10:remove
Unconfiguring omid service ...
2019-06-13 21:37:49 : Crontab no longer configured to update omi keytab.
Postuninstall_100:remove
Deleting omiusers group ...
Deleting omi service account ...
Postuninstall_1500:remove
Purging configuration files for omi (1.6.0.230) ...
Postuninstall_100:purge
touch: cannot touch Ã¢/opt/omi/.omi_not_deleteÃ¢: No such file or directory
Postuninstall_1500:purge
dpkg: warning: while removing omi, directory '/var/opt/omi/log' not empty so not removed
dpkg: warning: while removing omi, directory '/etc/opt/omi/ssl' not empty so not removed
dpkg: warning: while removing omi, directory '/etc/opt/omi/conf/sockets' not empty so not removed

column13: Making omi/installssllinks pick non-default openssl during start-up
column20:
I'm working on making the installation work of OMS / OMI / DSC / SCX with custom installation of OpenSSL 1.1 on an old distro (SLES11 SP4) which comes with default openssl 0.9.
Until know I solved all installation issue.
But at runtime OMI is running installssllinks which uses openssl to replace some links. So we would like that installssllinks to pick "openssl" from /opt/omi/bin if exist.
column21:
I'm working on making the installation work of OMS / OMI / DSC / SCX with custom installation of OpenSSL 1.1 on an old distro (SLES11 SP4) which comes with default openssl 0.9.
Until know I solved all installation issue.
But at runtime OMI is running installssllinks which uses openssl to replace some links. So we would like that installssllinks to pick "openssl" from /opt/omi/bin if exist.

column13: Change macos macro to avoid conflict with system defined macro
column20:
It seems like on recent builds of macOS (I think since 10.12) some of the system headers have defined the macos macro which conflicts with the -Dmacos macro we define when calling clang. This PR changes the macos macro used by omi to is_macos to avoid this conflict.
Before the PR running ./configure would fail with
*** UNABLE TO LOCATE FILE omi.version; USING VERSION 1.0.8.6 ***
*** Update build process to include omi.version from superproject! ***
checking whether pkg-config command is on the path... yes
created /Users/jborean/dev/omi/Unix/output
checking whether C compiler is on the path... yes
checking whether C compiler compiles... yes
checking whether C program executes... yes
checking for __FUNCTION__ macro or reserved word... yes
checking for __builtin_ctz... no
checking for __builtin_prefetch... yes
checking for sched_getcpu... no
checking for wcstoll... no
checking for wcsdup... no
checking for wcscasecmp, wcsncasecmp... no
checking for vswscanf... no
checking for va_copy... no
checking for backtrace... no
checking for __sync_synchronize... yes
checking for Atomic Intrinsic Functions... no
checking for sem_timedwait... no
checking for strerror_r... yes
checking for pthread_rwlock_t... no

That's because it's trying to compile and run the following code
cat > /tmp/pthread_rwlock_t_func.c <<EOF
#include <pthread.h>
int main()
{
    pthread_rwlock_t lock = PTHREAD_RWLOCK_INITIALIZER;
    (void)lock;
    return 0;
}
EOF

clang -g -O2 -Wall -I/usr/local/include -Dmacos -fvisibility=hidden -fstack-protector-all -DGSS_USE_IOV=1 -o /tmp/pthread_rwlock_t_func /tmp/pthread_rwlock_t_func.c
This fails with multiple errors of the following
In file included from /tmp/pthread_rwlock_t_func.c:1:
In file included from /Applications/Xcode.app/Contents/Developer/Platforms/MacOSX.platform/Developer/SDKs/MacOSX.sdk/usr/include/pthread.h:73:
In file included from /Applications/Xcode.app/Contents/Developer/Platforms/MacOSX.platform/Developer/SDKs/MacOSX.sdk/usr/include/pthread/qos.h:34:
/Applications/Xcode.app/Contents/Developer/Platforms/MacOSX.platform/Developer/SDKs/MacOSX.sdk/usr/include/sys/qos.h:132:31: error: expected ','
                        __QOS_CLASS_AVAILABLE(macos(10.10), ios(8.0)) = 0x21,
                                                   ^
/Applications/Xcode.app/Contents/Developer/Platforms/MacOSX.platform/Developer/SDKs/MacOSX.sdk/usr/include/sys/qos.h:126:31: note: expanded from macro
      '__QOS_CLASS_AVAILABLE'
#define __QOS_CLASS_AVAILABLE __API_AVAILABLE

After this change I am able to compile and build OMI on my macOS host. I'm mostly doing this so I have a libmi.dylib that is linked to OpenSSL 1.1 and not 1.0 that comes with PowerShell. If you wish to change the macro to another name, happy to change it to whatever you suggest.

column13: Fix up GSSAPI auth on macOS
column20:
The current code has a few problems when running on macOS

The HEIMDAL macro was not set on macOS, this causes it to try and load the wrong names.
GSS_C_NT_HOSTBASED_SERVICE is not used anywhere in the code (although it probably should be)

Planning on revisiting this in another PR as this is the recommended name type for the target name
In any case the name is invalid on macOS' Heimdal implementation so just removing it was easier for now


GSS_KRB5_NT_PRINCIPAL_NAME is valid for MIT krb5 but on Heimdal it needs to be accessed with __gss_krb5_nt_principal_name_oid_desc

Finally there was an issue when using an IP that was not routable. The getaddrinfo() function would set a NULL value for ai_canonname. This causes a seg fault when calling strlen(info->ai_canonname). Instead this just falls back to using the HTTP hostname that was set and let it fail later on.
Ultimately this enables Kerberos auth to work on macOS.
Unfortunately enabling NTLM auth through SPNEGO requires a lot more effort that I still need to investigate. Right now the code sends the NTLM negotiate and processes the challenge message but it fails to send the authenticate message causing a failure. Hopefully it's a simple fix I can address in another PR.

Planning on revisiting this in another PR as this is the recommended name type for the target name
In any case the name is invalid on macOS' Heimdal implementation so just removing it was easier for now


GSS_KRB5_NT_PRINCIPAL_NAME is valid for MIT krb5 but on Heimdal it needs to be accessed with __gss_krb5_nt_principal_name_oid_desc

Finally there was an issue when using an IP that was not routable. The getaddrinfo() function would set a NULL value for ai_canonname. This causes a seg fault when calling strlen(info->ai_canonname). Instead this just falls back to using the HTTP hostname that was set and let it fail later on.
Ultimately this enables Kerberos auth to work on macOS.
Unfortunately enabling NTLM auth through SPNEGO requires a lot more effort that I still need to investigate. Right now the code sends the NTLM negotiate and processes the challenge message but it fails to send the authenticate message causing a failure. Hopefully it's a simple fix I can address in another PR.

column13: Fix up GSSAPI auth on macOS
column20:
The current code has a few problems when running on macOS

The HEIMDAL macro was not set on macOS, this causes it to try and load the wrong names.
GSS_C_NT_HOSTBASED_SERVICE is not used anywhere in the code (although it probably should be)

Planning on revisiting this in another PR as this is the recommended name type for the target name
In any case the name is invalid on macOS' Heimdal implementation so just removing it was easier for now


GSS_KRB5_NT_PRINCIPAL_NAME is valid for MIT krb5 but on Heimdal it needs to be accessed with __gss_krb5_nt_principal_name_oid_desc

Finally there was an issue when using an IP that was not routable. The getaddrinfo() function would set a NULL value for ai_canonname. This causes a seg fault when calling strlen(info->ai_canonname). Instead this just falls back to using the HTTP hostname that was set and let it fail later on.
Ultimately this enables Kerberos auth to work on macOS.
Unfortunately enabling NTLM auth through SPNEGO requires a lot more effort that I still need to investigate. Right now the code sends the NTLM negotiate and processes the challenge message but it fails to send the authenticate message causing a failure. Hopefully it's a simple fix I can address in another PR.
column21: thanks for PR! this PR seems be not special to MacOS, and it seems a new feature about add HEIMDAL support while we currently used MIT Kerberos. And any new feature needs to be trigger by OMI PM/Manager internal and there is some process internal, if you want to do this new feature, the best way is to have a customer request a DCR internal, and then there might be some process to trigger it, PM will determine trigger it or not internal based on business justification, etc. just like that.

column13: Fix up GSSAPI auth on macOS
column20:
The current code has a few problems when running on macOS

The HEIMDAL macro was not set on macOS, this causes it to try and load the wrong names.
GSS_C_NT_HOSTBASED_SERVICE is not used anywhere in the code (although it probably should be)

Planning on revisiting this in another PR as this is the recommended name type for the target name
In any case the name is invalid on macOS' Heimdal implementation so just removing it was easier for now


GSS_KRB5_NT_PRINCIPAL_NAME is valid for MIT krb5 but on Heimdal it needs to be accessed with __gss_krb5_nt_principal_name_oid_desc

Finally there was an issue when using an IP that was not routable. The getaddrinfo() function would set a NULL value for ai_canonname. This causes a seg fault when calling strlen(info->ai_canonname). Instead this just falls back to using the HTTP hostname that was set and let it fail later on.
Ultimately this enables Kerberos auth to work on macOS.
Unfortunately enabling NTLM auth through SPNEGO requires a lot more effort that I still need to investigate. Right now the code sends the NTLM negotiate and processes the challenge message but it fails to send the authenticate message causing a failure. Hopefully it's a simple fix I can address in another PR.
column21:
this PR seems be not special to MacOS

I somewhat disagree, macOS uses Heimdal so fixing one fixes the other.

And any new feature needs to be trigger by OMI PM/Manager internal and there is some process internal

Disappointing that a "open source" project still needs to have an internal review that is completely opaque to contributors. You may as well just remove the repo and keep everything internal.
Ultimately this is maintained by some team in Microsoft. If they don't want fixes for their code that's contributed by outsiders then good luck to them. Feel free to take whatever you want from here in the future if you desire. I'll just maintain my own fork for my own purposes.

column13: Disbale SSL Renegotiation
column20:
OpenSSL >= 1.1.0h, use SSL_OP_NO_RENGOTIATION
OpenSSL <= 1.0.2, use SSL3_FLAGS_NO_RENEGOTIATE_CIPHERS
OpenSSL 1.1.0 - 1.1.0g, No way to disable renegotiation

column13: Enhanced security
column20:
Introduced authentication for omiserver in omiengine for user validation and PAM based user validation.
This authentication is secret string based. This secret string can be set only once, that is duirng omiegine bootup, any other afterwards  attempt to change the secret string will be ignored.
Default user type for running any scripts will be invalid user, so that user authencication can't be skipped. Additional validation for not allowing unauthorized user to proceed.
Fixed a Use-After-Free vulnerability where omiengine's connection with client get freed before omiegnine's connection with omiserver amd resulting in Use-After-Free vulnerability.
column21:
Introduced authentication for omiserver in omiengine for user validation and PAM based user validation.
This authentication is secret string based. This secret string can be set only once, that is duirng omiegine bootup, any other afterwards  attempt to change the secret string will be ignored.
Default user type for running any scripts will be invalid user, so that user authencication can't be skipped. Additional validation for not allowing unauthorized user to proceed.
Fixed a Use-After-Free vulnerability where omiengine's connection with client get freed before omiegnine's connection with omiserver amd resulting in Use-After-Free vulnerability.

column13: Spelling
column20:
This PR corrects misspellings identified by the check-spelling action.
The misspellings have been reported at jsoref@9ac24b5#commitcomment-57009226
The action reports that the changes in this PR would make it happy: jsoref@4bed8ca
Note: this PR does not include the action. If you're interested in running a spell check on every PR and push, that can be offered separately.
Disclaimer: GitHub does not like PRs w/ >250 commits (this has 465 at the time of filing). In general, reviewing windowed views is probably better than most alternatives (the standard git cli's diff output is fairly unhelpful for PRs like this).
Note: I fully expect to be asked to split this PR / reorganize it. If there are files that shouldn't be changed, let me know, dropping files is easy. If there are terms that can't be changed, that's also easy -- right now, a term is localized to a single commit, so dropping it means just dropping the commit.
It's possible for me to split by kind of content (comment vs code), but such things are moderately expensive and I try to do it as few times as possible and as late as possible.
I'll try to include annotations about the changes, but it'll take me a bit (it's a long PR)
